questions.text: Which of the following factors is true regarding the spread of dengue infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Aedes mosquito breeds natural dirty water bodies with a flight range of 100 meters.

options.label: B
options.text: Aedes survives best between humidity of 40-60% and temperature 19-25 0 C

options.label: C
options.text: A. aegypti, being a discordant feeder, results in clustering and generation of multiple dengue cases

options.label: D
options.text: Dengue cases among children report a more severe infection than the adult population

questions.correct_answer: C. A. aegypti, being a discordant feeder, results in clustering and generation of multiple dengue cases
questions.explanation:
Agent factors
  • Infection with any one serotype (DENV-1, 2, 3, and 4) confers lifelong immunity to that virus serotype (No cross-immunity)
  • Secondary infection with serotype 2 or multiple infections with different serotypes leads to severe immunological catastrophe. (DHF/DSS)

Vector

1. Aedes aegypti:

  • Less aggressive
  • Nervous feeder, discordant feeder (needs >1 feed): clustering of dengue cases (Option C)
  • Striped body appearance
  • Breed: Stagnant artificial water collections like tires, pots, buckets, etc.(Option A)
  • Flight range: Short range-100 meters.
  • Eggs: single and cigar-shaped
  • Larvae: siphon tube

2. Aedes albopictus:

  • More aggressive
  • Concordant feeder (1 feed is enough)

Disease transmission
  • Infective stage:
  • Reservoir:
    1. Man: day before symptom onset to 5th day
    2. Mosquito: remain infective lifetime (transovarial transmission)
  • Transmission cycle: Man-mosquito-man
  • Incubation period: 3 to 10 days

Host Factors
  • Children have a milder disease than adults.(Option D)
  • High risk: infants, elderly, obese, pregnant, peptic ulcer disease, menstrual disease, congenital disease, hemolytic diseases, NSAIDs.

Environmental Factors

 
  • Humidity - 60 to 80%
  • Temperature - 16 to 300C (Option B)
  • Endophagic and endophilic
  • 2°C increase in temperature: shortens extrinsic incubation period of infected mosquitoes
  • Rural spread is associated with water supply development, improved transport, and water scarcity.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of high fever, severe headache, and joint pain. Physical examination reveals a maculopapular rash and a positive tourniquet test. Laboratory tests reveal leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and mildly elevated liver enzymes. Based on the findings, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid antigen detection test

options.label: B
options.text: Blood culture

options.label: C
options.text: PCR for parasites

options.label: D
options.text: IgM ELISA

questions.explanation:
Uncategorized fever

  • No typical features

Break bone fever

(Classical dengue fever/ acute viral infection)
  • Retro orbital pain
  • Arthralgia
  • Severe myalgia and headache
  • Bimodal presentation of fever:
    • 39-40°C, peaks on days 1-2
    • Resurges: day 5-6
    • Recovery: day 7-10.
  • Rash: pin-point eruptions on the face, neck and chest followed by maculopapular or scarlatiniform on 3rd or 4th day.

Dengue hemorrhagic syndrome
  • Dengue fever + hemorrhagic manifestations(bleeding from any orifice)
  • Rash: Maculopapular/ Rubelliform
  • Lab Diagnosis
    • 20% increase in hematocrit
    • Thrombocytopenia (<1 lac)
  • Clinical diagnosis
    • Tourniquet test- >10 petechiae/ sq inch area

Dengue shock syndrome
  • Pulse pressure - <20 mmHg
  • Mean systolic pressure - <90mmHg: adults, <80 mmHg: children.

questions.text: All of the following are true about larval surveillance except?

options.label: A
options.text: Larval indices, such as the Breteau index, House index, and Container index, measure the density of larvae in a given area.

options.label: B
options.text: A House index is defined as percentages of houses or premises infested with larvae or pupae.

options.label: C
options.text: The Breteau index is the most specific criteria to measure dengue endemicity.

options.label: D
options.text: Airports should be kept at least 400m away around areas with A.aegypti index <1%

questions.correct_answer: A. Larval indices, such as the Breteau index, House index, and Container index, measure the density of larvae in a given area.
questions.explanation:
Larval Surveillance (density of larvae in the area)

Sampling unit: Houses or premises searched for water-holding containers.

 

House index: Number of houses positive for aedes larvae/number of houses searched.(Option B)

 

Container index: Number of containers positive/ number of containers checked.

 

Breteau index: The number of positive containers, and the number of houses checked.

  • Most sensitive to assess endemicity (Option C).
 

Aedes Aegypti Index:

  • Percentage of houses and their premises showing actual breeding of A. aegypti larvae.
  • Should not be >1%
  • Airports and seaports in endemic areas should be kept at least 400m around their premises free from the breeding of Aedes aegypti. (Option D)

Vector Control

Integrated vector management

  • Anti adult measures
  • Anti larval measures
  • Personal protection

Vaccine
  • Dengvarix (CYD-TDV): age 9-45 years

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a history of a dog bite he sustained 3 weeks ago and reports tingling at the site of the bite and difficulty swallowing. On examination, he appears anxious and is hypersensitive to stimuli. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Natural infection is caused by a fixed subtype of bullet-shaped DNA virus

options.label: B
options.text: Aerosol mode transmission is not reported in India

options.label: C
options.text: Licks on abraded skin are not considered a route of transmission

options.label: D
options.text: The highest rabies fatality in India is reported in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

questions.correct_answer: B. Aerosol mode transmission is not reported in India
questions.explanation:
Agent factor
  • Zoonotic disease with a 100% fatality rate
  • Lyssavirus type 1
    • Bullet-shaped RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae family). (Option A)
  • Two Types of Viruses:
    • Street virus:
      • Cause natural infection (Rabies)
      • Variable incubation period (7 days-months)
    • Fixed virus:
      • Fixed incubation period (5-7 days)
      • For vaccine production.
      • It does not demonstrate Negri bodies.

Host factors
  • Occupation
    • Dog handlers
    • Forest workers
    • Veterinarians.

Transmission
  • Incubation period: 2-8 weeks
  • Animal bite: Dog, Cat, Monkey, Bat or Wild animal (all need vaccination)
  • Licks on abraded skin are considered as the route of transmission. (Option C)
  • Rodent bites don't require vaccination.
  • In India:
    • Urban Rabies is very common.
    • Rabies is not found around water-bounded areas (Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands) (Option D)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was scratched by a cat during a hiking trip. The patient reports mild pain with a healthy wound that appears clean. The cat ran away immediately. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Clean the wound, prescribe antibiotics and tetanus toxoid.

options.label: B
options.text: Clean the wound, followed by a full course of anti-rabies vaccination

options.label: C
options.text: Clean the wound followed by anti-rabies vaccination and rabies immunoglobulin

options.label: D
options.text: Clean the wound with soap and water, followed by surgical debridement

questions.correct_answer: B. Clean the wound, followed by a full course of anti-rabies vaccination
questions.explanation:
Category

Exposure

Management

Class I

(OPTION A)

Licks and touch on intact skin (skin integrity not broken)
  • Local wound management: soap, running water, iodine tincture for 15-20 min.

Class II
(OPTION B)

Abrasion, laceration (skin integrity broken)
  • Local wound management
  • Immediate full course Rabies vaccination

Class III
(OPTION C)

Bleeding, licks on mucosa/ broken skin, deep tissue injury, all wild animal or bat bite
  • Wound management (avoid suturing)
  • Full course Rabies vaccination
  • Rabies immunoglobulin

THAI Red Cross Regimen (Updated)

Intradermal (ID) regimen:

  • Dose: 0.1ml, 8 doses (2 at every visit)
  • 4 visits scheduled on days: 0, 3, 7, 28
  • Administered on two sites simultaneously (2-2-2-2)
  • Day 0 is the first dose of vaccination
  • The National Rabies Control Program prefers ID over IM regimen.
 

Intramuscular (IM) regimen:

  • Administered as ID on Days: 0, 3, 7, and 28; and IM on Day 14 (2-2-2-2)

Essen Regimen (IM regimen)

Dose: 0.5ml (one complete vial used)

  • 5 visits scheduled on days: 0, 3, 7, 14, 28
  • Administered on one side only (1-1-1-1-1)
    • For adults: deltoid
    • For children: anterolateral aspect of the thigh.

Equine RIG

Human RIG
  • Not preferred
  • Dose: 40 IU/kg IM
  • Preferred
  • Dose: 20 IU/kg IM

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was bitten on the forearm by a stray dog. The bite wound is superficial with mild bleeding. Based on the Indian rabies management guidelines, which of the following is not recommended for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Intramuscular 0.1 ml vaccination on days 0, 3, 7 and 28 is preferred.

options.label: B
options.text: 70% of rabies immunoglobulin should be administered around the wound.

options.label: C
options.text: Deltoid is the recommended site for this patient.

options.label: D
options.text: Intradermal regimen consists of two doses administered at each of four sessions.

questions.correct_answer: A. Intramuscular 0.1 ml vaccination on days 0, 3, 7 and 28 is preferred.
questions.explanation:
THAI Red Cross Regimen (Updated)

Intradermal (ID) regimen: (Option A)

  • Dose: 0.1ml, 8 doses (2 at every visit) (Option D)
  • 4 visits schedule on days: 0, 3, 7, 28
  • Administered on two sites simultaneously (2-2-2-2)
  • Day 0 is the first dose of vaccination (not the first day of a dog bite)
  • The National Rabies Control Program prefers ID over IM regimen.
 

Intramuscular (IM) regimen:

  • Administered as ID on Days: 0, 3, 7, and 28; and IM on Day 14 (2-2-2-0-2)

Essen Regimen (IM regimen)

Dose: 0.5ml (one complete vial used)

  • 5 visits schedule on days: 0, 3, 7, 14, 28
  • Administered on one side only (1-1-1-1-1)
    • For adults: deltoid (not on the gluteal region)(Option C)
    • For children: anterolateral aspect of the thigh.
  • This regimen is not cost-effective.

Equine RIG

Human RIG
  • Not preferred
  • Dose: 20 IU/kg
  • Preferred
  • Dose: 40 IU/kg IM
  • 70% given around the wound/bite, and the rest given to distant areas (Option B)
  • Must be given on day 0 of vaccination and can be given up to 7 days after the bite.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after being bitten by a neighbour's dog on his right hand. He reports that he was bitten by a different dog five months ago and received the complete rabies vaccination series at that time. The wound appears clean with no signs of infection. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer a full course of rabies vaccine again (4 doses).

options.label: B
options.text: Administer two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

options.label: C
options.text: No rabies vaccine is needed due to recent vaccination.

options.label: D
options.text: Administer rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) and a full course of rabies vaccine (4 doses).

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the rabies vaccine are correct? Rabies vaccine is absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women. Immunocompromised individuals may require a full vaccination series even if previously vaccinated. The rabies vaccine should be administered intramuscularly in the deltoid region for adults. Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is required for all re-exposures, regardless of previous vaccination status. When a bite is from a vaccinated pet dog, post-exposure prophylaxis is not required.

options.label: A
options.text: Statements 1 and 4 are correct

options.label: B
options.text: Statements 2 and 5 are correct

options.label: C
options.text: Statements 3 and 5 are correct

options.label: D
options.text: Statements 2 and 3 are correct

questions.text: All are true regarding rabies vaccine except?

options.label: A
options.text: Can be given both pre-exposure and post-exposure.

options.label: B
options.text: Contains live attenuated virus.

options.label: C
options.text: Typically administered as a series of doses for complete protection.

options.label: D
options.text: Provide long term immunity after the initial series is completed.

questions.explanation:
Rabies Vaccine

Type

Human Diploid Cell Vaccine (HDCV) from inactivated (killed) virus

Dosage

Intramuscular (IM): 0.5 mL

Intradermal (ID): 0.1 mL

Administration Site

IM:

  • Deltoid muscle (upper arm) for adults and older children.
  • Anterolateral thigh for infants and younger children.
 

ID: (Shoulders) Over the deltoid.

Regimen

Given both pre-exposure and post-exposure in multiple doses.

Post-exposure:

  • Essen (IM): Days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28.

In 5 visits, given on 1 site.

  • Thai Red Cross (ID): Days 0, 3, 7, and 28

In 4 visits, the vaccine is given on 2 sites (Shoulders) simultaneously

Duration
  • After completing a full pre-exposure vaccination series, immunity against rabies can last many years.
  • May need re-exposure prophylaxis after 3 months.

Side effects:
  • Pain at the injection site, headache, dizziness, muscle aches, gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Severe (rare): Allergic reactions, neurological complications

questions.text: In an urban area with many rabies cases, which measures are most appropriate to control the disease and transmission?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass vaccination of domestic dogs and cats

options.label: B
options.text: Culling of stray dogs and cats

options.label: C
options.text: Quarantine of all suspected rabid animals

options.label: D
options.text: Public awareness campaigns about avoiding animal bites

questions.correct_answer: A. Mass vaccination of domestic dogs and cats

questions.text: A 35-year-old man returns from a Chennai trip and presents with fever, chills, and sweating. His blood smear shows ring forms in red blood cells. What is the most likely vector for this infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Anopheles culicifaciens

options.label: B
options.text: Anopheles stephensi

options.label: C
options.text: Anopheles fluviatilis

options.label: D
options.text: Anopheles minimus

questions.explanation:
Vector

Distribution

Anopheles culicifaciens

Rural and Peri-urban areas

Anopheles stephensi

Urban and Industrial areas

Anopheles fluvitilis

Hilly areas (Foothills)

Anopheles minimus

Northeastern states

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the epidemiology of malaria, except?

options.label: A
options.text: Anopheles mosquitoes are primarily nocturnal feeders.

options.label: B
options.text: Incidence is highest in tropical and subtropical regions

options.label: C
options.text: Quartan malaria is caused by Plasmodium malariae; fever cycles every 48 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: Can also be transmitted through blood transfusions and organ transplants.

questions.correct_answer: C. Quartan malaria is caused by Plasmodium malariae; fever cycles every 48 hours.
questions.explanation:
Malaria

Agent

Plasmodium species

 

Species

Type

Fever Cycle

P.falciparum

Malignant Tertian Malaria

Every 48 hours

P.vivax

Benign Tertian Malaria

Every 48 hours

P.malariae

Quartan Malaria

Every 72 hours

P.ovale

Ovale Malaria

Every 48 hours

P. knowlesi

Quotidian Malaria

Every 24 hours (daily)
 

Incubation Period: 7-30 days, depending on Plasmodium species

Vector

Female Anopheles mosquitoes

  • Behavior: Nocturnal feeders;(Option A) prefer to bite between dusk and dawn
  • Breeding Sites: Stagnant water bodies such as ponds, marshes, swamps, and artificial containers

Transmission
  • Bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes
  • Can be transmitted through blood transfusions and organ transplants.(Option D)

Host
  • Humans (Primary Host)

Higher risk in pregnant women, infants, and immunocompromised

  • Anopheles mosquitoes (Vector and Intermediate host)

Environmental Factors
  • Climate: Warm and Humid environment
  • Seasonality: Rainy seasons
  • Geographical Distribution:
  • Most prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions(Option B)
  • India: Endemic in several states, particularly in the northeastern states (Assam, Tripura, Meghalaya), Eastern states (Odisha, Jharkhand), and some parts of Maharashtra and Karnataka

Species

Type

Fever Cycle

P.falciparum

Malignant Tertian Malaria

Every 48 hours

P.vivax

Benign Tertian Malaria

Every 48 hours

P.malariae

Quartan Malaria

Every 72 hours

P.ovale

Ovale Malaria

Every 48 hours

P. knowlesi

Quotidian Malaria

Every 24 hours (daily)

questions.text: In a town of 5000 people, approximately 400 people are positive for malaria in a year. What is the annual parasite incidence in this town?

The local governing body of a population, which consists of 7000 people, decides to prepare smears from 700 infants, among which 140 of them were positive for malaria. What is the infant parasite rate in this population?
A district has a population of 7,50,000, among which 56,000 smears were prepared last year to detect malaria. What is this population's annual blood examination rate (ABER) for last year?

In a town of 4000 people in the last month, malarial smears have been prepared for 600 people who suffered acute febrile illness episodes, among which 85 were found to be positive for vivax, 25 for ovale and 10 for falciparum malaria. What is the updated slide positivity rate in this population?
